newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: US, Colombia seek extradition of accused drug lord.
newsitem.headline: US, Colombia seek extradition of accused drug lord.

text.p: Colombia added its voice on Saturday to calls by the United States for the extradition of a reputed Colombian drug lord caught in Venezuela.

Justo Pastor Perafan, allegedly the wealthiest man in Colombia with a personal fortune estimated at $12 billion, was arrested in Venezuela near the Colombian border on Friday and flown to Caracas where he is currently being held.
"We received Colombia's request this morning, and the United States' late yesterday," Venezuelan Foreign Minister Miguel Angel Burelli told Reuters in a telephone interview.

Burelli said U.S. ambassador to Venezuela John Maisto had formally filed a petition for Perafan's detention on Friday evening -- the first step towards an extradition. Perafan, who proclaims his innocence and says he has never set foot in the United States, is wanted on drugs charges in New York.

Colombia, meanwhile, has asked Venezuela to either deport or extradite Perafan. A Foreign Ministry release said Venezuela would decide in the next few days whether to proceed "with extradition or deportation to the country where the individual is most guilty and has the longest standing claim."
Both petitions will be forwarded to the Supreme Court on Monday, Burelli said. The court will make the final decision.
"I don't believe that this could lead to a conflict between Colombia and the United States," Burelli said. "If we're all fighting for the same, why should there be a fight?"

Perafan, 50, had been sought in Colombia for more than a year. After the arrest of the Rodgriguez Orejuela brothers and most other Cali drug Cartel leaders in 1995 and 1996, he was allegedly the top Colombian drug lord still at large.
